intro: Tithymalus cadrilateri, commonly known as the four-angled tithymalus, is a flowering plant native to certain regions of southern Europe. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes parsley and carrots, and is characterized by its distinctive, angular stems. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. Its leaves are lance-shaped and often have a mild, aromatic scent. Tithymalus cadrilateri is typically found in rocky or dry soils and thrives in full sun.
